newsitem.title: USA: FORECAST - Midwest U.S. newspapers Q3 EPS seen up.
newsitem.headline: FORECAST - Midwest U.S. newspapers Q3 EPS seen up.

text.p: Midwest-based U.S. newspaper companies, benefitting from plummeting newsprint prices, are expected to report strong third quarter earnings.
"We're expecting double-digit earnings growth across the board," said PaineWebber media analyst William Drewry.
Employment demand continued to be strong, driving help wanted advertising results, Drewry added. He also noted that display advertising was doing better than many had expected.
"Top line growth in the (newspaper) sector has held its ground," said Merrill Lynch analyst Lauren Fine.

Multi-media giant Tribune Co was paying about $590 per metric ton of newsprint, after a peak of $735 per ton in the first quarter, said Nesbitt Burns analyst James Goss. The average newsprint price it paid during 1995 was $650 per ton.
Tribune also continued to build strength through broadcasting and educational media acquisitions, analysts said.
Steven Barlow of Smith Barney said an analysts' briefing with Tribune management last week reenforced his view that the company's acquisition strategy was "focused rather than willy-nilly."
Analysts said easy comparisons on newsprint versus a year ago should also help third-quarter results at Indianapolis, Ind.-based Central Newspapers Inc and St. Louis-based Pulitzer Publishing Co.
But moves into electronic publishing and use of the Internet as a vehicle for selling advertising are unlikely to have a meaningful impact for some time.

John Morton, a Lynch Jones & Ryan analyst, said most newspaper-oriented companies are testing the Internet's potential. "It's still a drop in the bucket and in five years it'll probably be five drops in the bucket," he said.
"Clearly it (the Internet) will be important some day," said Morton. And newspapers, with their strong data bases, are uniquely equipped to do well in the electronic arena, Morton added.

Merrill Lynch's Fine said Chicago-based Hollinger International Inc should post a strong quarter, though she had no formal estimate in part because of a restructuring the company underwent last year. In the 1995 third quarter, it reported earnings of $0.12 per share.
U.S. FIRST CALL CONSENSUS QTLY EARNINGS FORECASTS:
